node.text:
Under the watchful eye of patriarch Gianni, Poderi Gianni Gagliardo makes focused, precise wines – particularly, single-vineyard Barolos – in the Langhe. Gianni started making wines back in the 1970s, however, it wasn’t until the 1980s that his wines came into their own. Today, the winemaking responsibilities are in the hands of his three sons: Stefano, Alberto and Paolo. The winery owns many small plots of land that are all distributed in five different villages with varying soil compositions. We especially like the younger wines here but don’t miss their special Barolos that are released after an extended aging in bottle (Archivio Storico): they show the wonder in aged Barolos. 

In this video Stefano Gagliardo presents Barolo del Comune di La Morra Poderi, shown at the Great Wines of the World Autumn Edition in Hong Kong this month.

node.text:
Anselmo Guerrieri Gonzaga, the owner of Italian winery Tenuta San Leonardo, sits down with James to talk about the history and current winemaking style of San Leonardo. "All our red wines are still only made in concrete vats," Anselmo says. "We do not use any stainless steel. There is no refrigeration, no heating, no [commercial] yeasts, we only use indigenous yeasts." He adds: "I am not against technology, it's just that in this area, the climate is so fine that it's easy to make red wines, and we can do them in a proper way to respect the terroir."

node.text:
In this tasting of Vega Sicilia's 2017 and 2018 releases, James speaks with Gonzalo Iturriaga, the head winemaker at Macàn and Vega Sicilia, and Pablo Alvarez, the owner and CEO of Vega Sicilia.

Gonzalo explains that 2017 was one of the more challenging vintages recently, due to the incredibly hot weather that they experienced in Toro, Spain, but that the 2018 vintage is "more elegantly balanced," which is why he favors the latter vintage. Check out the video to hear their opinions on the current winemaking trend in Spain and to learn more about Vega Sicilia's latest releases.

node.text:
Artadi owner/winemaker Carlos Lopez de Lacalle says the 2018 vintage came from a warm summer with a slightly cold September. "From that we got all this fresh, elegant, ripe fruit aromas with great balance and a lot of tension." James says the Artadi 2018 wines are good now, but asks Carlos how he thinks they will age. "For us, a wine that ages needs to be drinkable when it's young," Carlos says, adding that he's certain the 2018s will age, given their ripe tannins and higher acidity. "Now if you taste your wines, if you want to make comparisons it's like Burgundy now," James said of the 2018s compared with 10 years ago. "It's really just fresh, and really fine tannins ... and you can see the differences in all the different crus, and I think that's really exciting."

node.text:
JamesSuckling.com has always promoted village and sub-appellations for Chianti Classicos, and we are happy the rule changes pertaining to the sub-appellations are taking effect. 

Our video series on Chianti Classicos covers each comune, and includes interviews with owners, enologists and members of the Chianti Classico Consortium. It looks at their wines, their comunes, the history and the future of Chianti Classico. 

Of all the comunes of Chianti Classico, the two we'll meet in episode eight are without a doubt the least known of all: Tavarnelle Val di Pesa and Poggibonsi. Given their relative obscurity, we thought it a good idea to group them together. Most of the land in these two comunes isn't actually Chianti Classico at all, extending instead into the realms of just Chianti. Both also give home to the largest and most urbanized towns of the region. 

Nevertheless, there are one or two excellent producers who fight against the odds. One is Johannes Davaz, a Swiss whose relatives still make pinot near Lichtenstein. Today he owns his own small but first-class property in Tavarnelle Val di Chianti Classico called "Poggio Al Sole." He explains how it can be difficult making wine in an unknown area, especially since he feels his wines belong more to the much better-known comune of Greve. 

In the comune of Poggibonsi, there are only two serious wine producers. Cinciano is one of them, but as commercial director Angelo Dalbello explains, the comune has always been important for other reasons – back in medieval times it was an important stop on the ancient Via Francigena, one of the great ways of the ancient world. 

Similarly to Tavarnelle, it's an especially frustrating situation for Cinciano because their winery actually sits on a hill above the large town, where, as Angelo asserts, ventilation, exposure and soils are all top quality. Angelo is looking to promote his brand first and foremost. He makes a good point that when it comes to quality – ultimately it's up to the producer to prove his worth. 

#Italy #ItalianWine #ChiantiClassico #ChiantiClassicoDiaries #wine #winenerd #winestagram #winery #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling

node.title: CHIANTI CLASSICO DIARIES: TAVARNELLE VAL DI PESA POGGIBONSI

node.text:
James recently tasted the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum, which impressed him so much he said to Lucie Pereyre de Nonacourt, who represents the fourth generation at Champagne Laurent-Perrier, and Edouard Cossy, the company's global director: "The aromas were amazing. Honestly, I can't think of a more beautiful Champagne with the aromas... that sort of brioche and tarte au limon." 

Lucie tells the story of how her grandfather founded the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée. When he became director of the house, he realized he had to have a prestige cuvée. He based the creation of his cuvée on a unique blend, which would take the champagne further in terms of quality and thus achieve his goal of recreating the perfect year – "one that nature cannot provide." 

Check out their conversation now to learn more about the Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum and when to expect its release.

node.text:
American Pinot Noir producer Adam Lee wears many hats: he was a co-founder of Siduri Wines (and remains a consultant and winemaker), founded the Clarice Wine Company, and co-founded Beau Marchais Wine with famed vintner Philippe Cambie. 

In this chat with JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt, Adam talks about his approach in making pinot through whole-cluster fermentation and why he varied whole-cluster percentages for the 2017-19 vintages. Claire also asks Adam for his thoughts on the uncertainty of the final product and whether whole-cluster fermentation can affect a wine negatively, to which Adam responds: "Yes, there is a risk you could have unripe stems ... [but] one of the things I have found on stem ripeness is it has to do with the length of hang time and does not correlate with sugar maturity." 

Check out the rest of their conversation for more of Adam's thoughts on pinots and their future on the West Coast.

#California #CalifornianWine #ClariceWineCompany @claricewinecompany #BeauMarchaisWine @beaumarchaiswines #pinotnoir #westcoastwines #wine #winemaker #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

Great Wines of the World Grand Masterclass began today featuring 177 wines from 88 wineries. Wine trade and keen consumers were happy to compare vintages, regions, countries as well as try lots of new releases.

node.text:
James sits down with Michel Friou and Manuel Louzada, the winemaker and managing director, respectively, at Viña Almaviva in Chile to discuss the 2019 Epu, which James calls a "beautiful second wine." 

"One question is, how did you finally decide to do a second wine and why?" James asks Manuel. "It's a very delicious wine." 

"After 25 years we definitely believed that we already have brand recognition, brand awareness, that Almaviva was already recognized because of the quality of the wine and because of its reputation," Manuel says. "From a business standpoint, the decision was, 'Let's focus on Almaviva ... and then afterward we started again in 2006 [with Epu] ... in basically two markets: Chile and Brazil.'" 

They also talk about the decision to sell Epu through La Place de Bordeaux, where negociants will redistribute it throughout the world. Check out the video now for the full conversation. 

#Chile #ChileanWine #MaipoValley #MaipoValleyWine #Almaviva #AlmavivaWinery #AlmavivaWine @almavivawinery  #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt sits down with Domaine Serene Winemaker Michael Fay to ask about the proportion of pinot noir versus chardonnay grapes used at the winery, as well as its plans for making more chardonnay. 

"We're definitely bullish on chardonnay," Michael says. "We really believe in three things for chardonnay that really make this style of chardonnay that we want. We're really only interested in planting chardonnay in high elevations, on Jory soils ... and using Dijon clones, which are early-ripening clones of chardonnay." 

Watch their video interview for free now at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Florent Genty, commercial director of Chateau Nenin, presents Chateau Nenin Pomerol 2018. This wine will be shown at the Grand Tasting Sessions held at Four Seasons Hotel Hong Kong from Sept. 2-3. 

Chateau Nenin is a large estate by Pomerol standards, with 32 hectares of vineyards in production. The owners of this estate, the Delons who also own the famous second growth of Leoville Las Cases, are starting to use this to their advantage, making rigorous selections at harvest time and favoring low-yielding, older vines. The fine tannins in these silky Right Bank wines make them ethereal — try them for yourself and you’ll soon understand why.

node.text:
NEW ON JAMESSUCKLING.COM: POISED AND ELEGANT CHINESE WINES? HUAILAI COULD HOLD KEY TO UNLOCKING GREATNESS

Ningxia epitomizes China’s resolve to establish a modern wine epicenter in the East, and with recent guidelines issued by the government to lift the region’s wine trade, there will be a lot more happening on the plains of the Gobi Desert. But even though the north-central part of the country is churning out rich, generous and excellent wines, we couldn’t stop asking ourselves: Is it the wonderland for great wines from China? 

Although some see parallels between Ningxia and the well-established Bordeaux, the one place in China that might bear a better resemblance to the classic French wine-growing region is Huailai, which lies just to the west of China’s teeming capital, Beijing. Forty wineries are scattered throughout the region, which is set amid gently rolling hills and the gigantic Guanting Reservoir. 

Although producers have been making wine here since the 1970s, it has only been over the past few years that local, mostly independent makers have started pulling off staggering, world-class wines. For a long time, producers in Huailai, such as Martin Vineyard, bought grapes from local farmers and sold bulk wine to a few wine conglomerates, including the state-owned GreatWall, Dynasty and Changyu. 

Learn more about the developing winemaking landscape and what it looks like today in Huailai in Associate Editor Zekun Shuai’s latest report at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
NEW WINE PODCAST FEATURING VEGA SICILIA’S GONZALO ITURRIAGA AND PABLO ALVAREZ 

James has noticed that there seems to be a trend in using less wood for wine now, and asks Gonzalo and Pablo if they are following the same methods in their winemaking for Vega Sicilia. 

Gonzalo, the winemaker for the Spanish estate, says they are, with the result that “when you taste the wine you can taste the grapes, and there is a trend for making more elegant wines... It doesn’t matter what you do in the end, when [the terroir is] great and strong, it comes through." 

Pablo, the CEO, also shares that he enjoys the 2017 more than the 2016: “It’s rich; it’s not too ripe and dry. The quality of tannins is very polished, very linear with an underlying freshness and coolness of character.” 

Check out the JamesSuckling.com Wine Podcast to hear more of Gonzalo’s and Pablo’s thoughts on why the 2017 turned out so well in Toro, Spain – listen for free now at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Participants of an exclusive masterclass today for Great Wines of the World Edition 3 Hong Kong tasted @jamessucklingwinecentral may have been the first consumers and trade in the world to experience Napa Valley’s prestigious 2016 Promontory before its release early next year with owner Bill Harlan via Zoom. The tasting included five vintages of Promontory including 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015 and 2016. The 2015 is the current vintage on the market. 

Harlan took the group through an online tour and discussion of the vineyards and winery including lengthy conversation on geology and terroir as well as winemaking. The takeaway was that Promontory is coming to its own as a very unique cabernet sauvignon-based red that impressively communicates the mountainous region where the vineyard is planted just south of Harlan’s other vineyards Harland Estate and Bond. Harlan loves the “transparency and vibrance” of the 2016, which may be its best ever according to James.

#GreatWinesoftheWorld2021 #California #CalifornianWine #NapaValley #NapaValleyWine #PromontoryWinery @promontorywine #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
Today’s masterclass during the Great Wines of the World Edition 3 in Hong Kong showcased a diverse line up of Chardonnays from both the Old and New World @jamessucklingwinecentral. Led by Kevin Davy from the JamesSuckling.com tasting team, the masterclass focused on understanding the adaptable character of the varietal and its expressions depending on the different terroirs, climates and winemaking techniques.

While the guests appreciated the freshness and natural balance of the old world chardonnays, they were also charmed by the influence of winemaking and the use of Oak in shaping unique characters in the new world wines selection. The chardonnays tasted included:

* Concha y Toro Chardonnay Valle de Limarí Amelia 2019 (94 pts)
* Joseph Drouhin Beaune 1er Cru Clos des Mouches Blanc 2017 (94 pts)
* Domaine Drouhin Chardonnay Willamette Valley Dundee Hills Arthur 2017 (93 pts)
* Marimar Estate Chardonnay Sonoma County Russian River Valley La Masía Don Miguel Vineyard 2018 (92 pts)
* Newton Chardonnay Napa Valley Unfiltered 2018 (94 pts)
* Peter Michael Winery Chardonnay Sonoma County Knights Valley Ma Belle-Fille 2018 (97 pts)
* Planeta Chardonnay Sicilia Menfi 2018 (93 pts)
* Sauska Chardonnay Tokaj Birs 2017 (93 pts)
* Silver Heights Chardonnay Ningxia Family Reserve 银色高地霞多丽家族珍藏 2019 (92 pts)

#GreatWinesoftheWorld2021 #chardonnay #OldWorldwine #NewWorldwine #conchaytoro  @conchaytoro #domainedrouhinoregon @domainedrouhinoregon #marimarestate @marimarestate #newtonvineyard @newtonvineyard #petermichaelwinery @petermichaelwinery #planetawinery @planetawinery #silverheightswinery @silverheightsvineyard #wine #winetasting #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
Silver Heights is a family-run business in Ningxia, China, and with the talented Emma Gao as winemaker, it was among the wineries that won early praise as China’s wine industry began its rapid rise. It continues to make classy cabernet blends and round but drinkable chardonnays, as well as good pinot noir and marselan. The wines always possess a well-judged balance between richness and freshness, and it recently converted to biodynamic farming. Their new winery was recently completed, and their quest is to make wines that are as authentic and natural as possible, and for the world, not just Chinese drinkers.

Emma Gao, owner and winemaker of Silver Heights, presents Silver Heights Family Reserve Chardonnay 2019. This wine was shown at Great Wines of the World Autumn Edition Grand Tastings in Hong Kong.

node.text:
The U.S., France and Australia gave us some bottles for thought in our August tastings, including Australia’s Jim Barry Shiraz Clare Valley The Armagh 2017. The Armagh is one of the Jim Barry estate’s most acclaimed wines, and although the 2017 didn’t score as highly as previous vintages, our tasters found that it had “vibrant blueberries, violets and floral spices with a redder-fruit spectrum leading the nose. The palate has a lithe, juicy feel and the oak sits in a gently creamy layer of redder plum and berry flavors. An elegant, athletic Armagh and one that trades on acidity and more medium-weight tannin structure.” 

You can read our Monthly Tasting Report for free by clicking on the link in the bio. It comes with over 2,300 tasting notes!

node.text:
On Thursday, Accolade Wines showcased soon-to-be-released vintages of their top Australian brands ahead of their official launch later this year. Members of Hong Kong’s wine and media industry tasted new wines from House of Arras in Tasmania, founding winery Hardy’s in McLaren Vale, and Grant Burge and St Hallet in Barossa.
 
Accolade Global Director Nigel Sneyd MW joined host Martin Newell, Accolade’s general manager for Northeast Asia, via Zoom to discuss and introduce the wines. Guests had the opportunity to taste the new releases side by side with back vintages, such as Hardy’s Eileen Hardy 2010 Chardonnay and 2008 Shiraz, as well as Arras E.J. Carr Late Disgorged 2006, which spent 14 years on lees.
 
The tasting highlighted the move towards fresher, less opulently-oaked styles of shiraz-based reds, alongside the ageability of the top cuvées, with guests particularly impressed by the freshness, intensity and tension of the 2010 Eileen Hardy Chardonnay, a blend of 72 percent fruit from Tasmania and 28 percent from the Yarra Valley. The wines were paired with a lunch prepared by Richard Ekkebus at Amber.
 
Photos by Accolade Wines. | @accoladewines

node.text:
Austria’s Weingut Nigl received outstanding scores for their 2020 vintages in our latest Weekly Tasting Report. 

The Nigl Gruner Veltliner Kremstal Ried Pellingen El private 2020 (97 points) showed stunning exotic-fruit, chamomile and spice aromas, while the elegant Kremstal Ried Hochäcker El Private 2020 (also 97 points) showed notes of stone fruit nutmeg and wildflowers. 

Pictured here is Martin Nigl Jr., who works in the vineyards and cellar with his father, the founder and winemaker of Weingut Nigl. 

You can read more on how Austrian (and German, Spanish and Italian) wines fared in our latest Weekly Tasting Report by clicking on the link in the bio.

node.text: Drank two epic syrahs last night. Really amazing wines. I have been to both vineyards. And the old vines of Tyrrell’s Old Patch are simply amazing and on their own rootstock planted back in 1867. #syrah #wine #winelover

NEW WINE PODCAST FEATURING TENUTA SAN LEONARDO 

In the latest JamesSuckling.com Wine Podcast, James and Tenuta San Leonardo owner Anselmo Guerrieri Gonzaga discuss the Italian winery’s excellent 2017 riesling. 

Anselmo also explains that while he is not a fan of oak in red wines, he is "a big fan of oak in white wines. When they’re well-made with great acidity, I think it’s just something that’s unbelievable, the grace that it can give to white wine.” Anselmo sees his rieslings as a cross – somewhere between Burgundy and German style, although he said he aims to give his rieslings their own unique complexity. 

Here, Anselmo talks about the development of the labels on various San Leonardo wines, starting with the initial design on the 1982, which was the first vintage created by his father. 

Check out the JamesSuckling.com Wine Podcast for free now at JamesSuckling.com.
